author: {'steamid': '76561198001656242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1439489340}
review: Ubermosh is a fun game for what it is. You try to get a new high score slicing through monsters and picking up guns. Each run is only 90 seconds, so you'll have intense fun. It's a kind of coffee break game where obsessing about improving your high score is the main provider of the entertainment. There's not a lot of content here, but what is there is good and worth the 3 bucks! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YPt90Nnm7Ak

author: {'steamid': '76561198025457048', 'num_games_owned': 839, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1479923188}
review: Ubermosh is a quick game for players who like frenetic games and screen-shake. Each game session is at most 90 seconds in a hostile environment full of aliens. It is the second journey of the indie lonewolf Walter Machado, who evolves his skills as a developer with every game he makes. Ubermosh delivers a fantastic mechanic, where the player is able to cut the enemy's bullets and thus kill more enemies. In addition, some weapons complete what you can do with the character. The game has a very 90's vibe with a sovereign Cologne in the sky where the game takes place. The music is amazing and makes a perfect match with the frenetic pace of the game. The game has some issues due to being developed by just one guy. It would be interesting if there were a lot more of content, different scenarios, a sense of progression. For me the ideal would be a roguelike with elements that would make each of the 90 seconds different from each other. The achievementes could also be better used in the game. Nevertheless, the price it's being sold is very fair for the casual fun that the game delivers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070993526', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1535158051}
review:
Love the soundtrack.
Love the bloody visuals.
Like the fast-paced simple gameplay.

Don't like the instant cut to black upon death (a bit jarring).
Don't like how excessively controllers vibrate or how stiff the analog/joystick feels (except for the Kensai class, controller sword-play is perfect)
Don't like how I can't change my colour scheme (minor-est of minor gripes)

Hope there are more gamemodes in the future, perhaps adding some more objectives down the line would be good.
Overall it's and fun, a bit unrefined but definitely showing potential.

review: Simples, dinÃ¢mico e desafiador. O jogo Ã© excelente em sua simplicidade e ambientaÃ§Ã£o, com inimigos que dÃ£o um bom grau de dificuldade e que agora ficou mais interessante com os mods alternativos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059561891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1438473256}
review:
Ubermosh is very simple but elegant in its design. You have exactly 90 seconds to destroy as many of your enemies as possible and of course not die in the process. This game is all about fast replay, like arcade games of yesteryear. Armed with a sword you will dance across the battlefield weaving death while using your enemies weapons against them. For an EA title this all works very well and and the controls feel very tight. As far as difficulty goes, Ubermosh is far from an easy game but death doesn't feel cheating usually, unless an enemy teleports on top of you. One thing to keep in mind though is that you pay for what you get here. While the visuals, music, and gameplay of Ubermosh are fantastic. It's short, repetitive and mostly involves killing everything in sight. Beating your own score is all that is currently involved in the game. Hopefully leaderboards and more features to shake things up a little are on the way. (Bosses would be sweet.) If you are the type of person who played Flash games for hours trying to top leaderboards or you enjoy games where you slaughter endlessly. Ubermosh is going to satisfy. Those looking for something more complex and feature rich, may be disappointed. So get your twitch fingers ready and sharpen those eyes and play some Ubermosh!

I made a video preview to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/ii2Toy60H5U
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

author: {'steamid': '76561198057473202', 'num_games_owned': 810, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1491265234}
review:
This game offers two things in spades:
1. Action
2. Simplicity

The music is great. Simple and effective, action packed tunes. The controls are responsive and about as "pick up and play" as you can get.

Many games have good reviews with long hours of gameplay. This game's strength lays in the fact that you don't have to play it long to have a great experience. There's so much action packed into every minute, you don't need to play long hours to get the most out of the game. That being said, I can see myself putting in more time in the future because of the high difficulty and replayability. 

In short: if you want a game that offers a huge blast of action in a very short period of time, this is the game for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042842903', 'num_games_owned': 2802, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1523562251}
review:
[h1]The colony provides us everything.
...Except for violence.[/h1]

In short my thoughts should look like this:
[b]"I've never felt a tension like this before."[/b](c)

In longer, thou...

This game is one helluva syringe of adrenaline straight into your brain.
UBERMOSH is fast, furious, energetic and brutal, with one [b][i]aaaaaamaaaaaaayziiiiiing[/i][/b] soundtrack which i wanna listen my whole life.
Gameplaywise, 90 seconds per round is excellent idea for a fast and furious game like this one, blade and guns equally feellable and just cool to use.
Could be more enemy types, though.

None the less, great game, and even greater for it's price.

I will play every new build of this one.

And, again

[h1]WELCOME TO UBERMOSH[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198058875696', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1692470596}
review:
this game is definitely already worth the money I spent for it in Early Access. 

the blade animation and sound work so well together to make using it feel great. 
and then you pick up [u] the guns! [/u] the screen shake with each blast or pulse (depending on what you picked up) is so satisfying. 
not to mention the music! it's all creating a great atmosphere in the 90 s of frenzy; fighting completely overwhelmed by enemies spawning around you. 
the current build has added different modes of play: giving you access to the top weapon from start with penalty of less respawns or a challenge mode with blade only and additional respawns.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987882027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1495290280}
review:
Super addictive, fast-paced, futuristic and challenging game! The game is quite simple: within 70 seconds you have to survive against hordes of monsters by picking up different weapons and make use of your melee weapon do block enemy bullets. However, despite the simplistic gameplay,hitting the right commands on time is quite tough at the beginning but you get better and better every run..
Just get it ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198067692156', 'num_games_owned': 1507, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1538221567}
review:
Oh man, this is even more frustrating than Nuclear Throne - I tell myself I'll rage quit the next round from the start... for 20 rounds :)

With incredibly responsive controls, this game delivers brutal carnage of enemies coming from all directions and requires very decent player reponse time.

I really like the concept of playing against yourself - just the number of poor bastards you slain matters and for each 10 of them, you get a skull on the lady's armor. You see your best and you play to improve, to become the ultimate bullet cutting ninja of doom and more importantly, to become better than your older self, which always a good thing, right?

I slain 97 bastards during my first half an hour of raging with this game using controller - how many can you slay before you run out of respawn cores?

author: {'steamid': '76561198129133804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1563631554}
review:
UPDATE 0.011
What can I say?
No early access game, for me, has shown as much potential as this one. I can't wait until development goes further, and we get new gamemodes and such. The game feels amazingly smooth, and though I disapprove of controllers for this genre of game, I found the control scheme tight and well programmed.
The awesome feeling you get when you kill tons of enemies with one shot, or one bullet slice is unrivalled in the market right now.
For a game so cheap, this is the intense action I know you crave.

My one problem is the difficulty.

The game has two difficulties, and I got Blade Saint on both before I had hit the half an hour timer. I know this will be improved in further updates, as it is just early access, but I needed at least one criticism. This is a review, not free advertisement.

UPDATE 0.012
The game is running slower, there are constant graphical glitches and I'm having trouble with lag when you change weapon. A game which was working so well has been set back by one update. I'm still going to recommend it, because I believe that the developer can pull it out of this laggy, glitchy update.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052147863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1498994456}
review:
I started playing UBERMOSH today with the "Blade Saint" patch and am very glad that I did.

The game translates to a controller very well feeling both powerful and deadly at the same time with both sticks used all the time and heavy, nicely synched controller vibration to really absorb you into the fast paced fun.

It took me five minutes to really get into the thrill.

This is only the beginning. I am excited to see what UBERMOSH comes up with in the next update!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043250032', 'num_games_owned': 2464, 'num_reviews': 329, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1441323293}
review:
UBERMOSH is a fast-paced cyberpunk action game that is currently available through Steam Early Access. In UBERMOSH you get thrown into a mosh pit full of crazy enemies armed to the teeth and you have to use your katana to cut the bullets up and send them back to where they came from! Killing enemies lets you pick up their guns so you can bring down fire upon your enemies from your own weapons too!

Since UBERMOSH is in Early Access and is also extremely cheap I won't mention anything along the lines of 'lack of content' in my Early Access review.

+Awesome pixel art style
+A kickass soundtrack
+Well designed enemies and weapons
+The weapons that are currently available are varied so you get a lot of different types of projectiles flying all over the place
+Each round is ninety seconds (not that you'll ever make it to ninety seconds) so it's possible to have a couple of quick games even if you're short on time
+Excellent value for money even if you only play it for an hour since it has such a low price
+Simple controls (KB&M)
+Provides a good challenge but the more you play the better you get, at least that's what I found
+Three playable classes have been introduced, they add new playstyles to the game but there is still the no-class mode which is what the game was pre-update

-I don't see you being able to play for more than an hour or two but for the price that isn't too bad

Here's a short gameplay video I recorded:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DwkeOsMvkow

Verdict:
Essential Purchase (9/10)

UBERMOSH is a fantastic, fast-paced action game with a cool cyberpunk style, awesome pixel graphics, a fantastic soundtrack and great value for money. If you still haven't picked this game up then you're doing yourself a disservice.

[i]No drama, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/justreviews]Just Reviews[/url]?[/i]

El K.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984165726', 'num_games_owned': 1229, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1433611176}
review: Recommended mostly for the sound track. An interesting "Rouge-Like" shooter game where you deflect bullets with your sword like a jedi and shoot bad guys. That's about it so far. My one gripe with the game is that the aspect ratio is too tight and you can hardly see anything around you, causing you to get blind sided by enemies you couldn't see until they're right up your rear. Other than that, it's an ok game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066492566', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1442788896}
review:
Out of the 33 minutes I have played this game, I have come to the conclusion that UBERMOSH is one of the greatest dual-stick shooters ever (at least to me). This game is definitely one of those games you can pick up and play for a short time and still feel extremely satisfied in the end; given its fast paced action and booming soundtrack. I mean, it is impossible, at least for me, to stop clicking or pulling the right trigger to fire as you frantically kill off many enemies trying to take you out.

Plus, this is the first Early Access game I purchased, and I can tell you that I do not regret that purchase one bit.

If you're a fan of dual-stick shooters like, say Robotron: 2084, Total Carnage, or Zombie Apocalypse (using those three as examples), PLEASE give this game a shot. I'm glad I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027406905', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1464733004}
review:
Badass game for sure.  And I know this game is early access so there's more to come... but here's my review.

Pros: :D
I like the graphics
It's named UBERMOSH \m/
The music is FREAKING AWESOME.
I like how it's fast paced and hordes of enemies come at you from everywhere
It's not wave based(in my opinion the pace would be too slow if it was)
I like the screen shake
very nice sound effects
It's highly satisfying to kill enemies(more so with a sword) which is important to me :P

Cons: D:
I want to give the game constructive criticism but I cannot think of that many flaws. I mean it is early access and all.
-There's not a lot of weapon variety at the moment 
-Repetitiveness could burn you out after a while


Suggestions:
-It would be cool to have a shop you could spend points you earn from rounds, or better yet have a system like Super House of Dead Ninjas where kills unlock you different colored gear, to different weaponry, etc..
-Customization imo might be cool
-implement a health pack drop every so often from enemies or a timed drop.
-Perhaps different abilities such as buffed rate of fire, a shield that sponges one hit, a timed weapon that's stronger than the red laser shotgun(for example a blue laser shotgun that fires more projectiles that only lasts 15 seconds)
-Create more maps(in general) but also make it to where you fight different species and therefore find yourself a new arsenal of weaponry from the corpses.
-More game modes.

that's about it for UBERMOSH atm. I am looking forward to updates.
Thanks for reading everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034991718', 'num_games_owned': 259, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1436226771}
review:
[Early Access Review]
Short review:
Its really fun, its fast paced, lots of killing, its in development, so that means that they will add more stuff, its cheap!... You should get it
(it still needs lots of work, but its fun)

Long review:
Like i said, its really fun and fast, it actually makes you want to start over and over as soon as you die.

Ill start by saying:
I know its in development, and thats the reason im going to express mi opinion of what could make this fun game an even greater game.

- Problem when dying:
Something i found a bit annoying (its not  a big deal, but it bothers me a bit) everytime you die it immediately throws you to a screen saying you died then main screen. And also, sometimes you dont even know what kills you, you simply die  (even when you thought no one was around)

- Probable Solution: 
Add a screen in game when you die with the basic "Retry - Quit" Options.
and maybe add a "Killed by _____" in that same screen.

- More Game Modes: 
- Time Survival with 3 lives, killing an elite or boss (you will see what im talking about below) get extra time bonus, or a extra life, everytime you die you get -15 sec or something like that.
A Game mode that will allow you to use the perks and abilities (see at the end of the review)

- Problem Variety of enemies:
its cool killing enemies over and over again, but since its a really fast paced game where enemies die in 1 shot (no matter which weapon you have, i will talk about this later) you start seeing the same enemies over and over again.

- Solution:
 Im pretty sure this will be done, which is adding more kinds and types of enemies, but id be cool to see Elite enemies, maybe bosses? (which can handle way more than just 1 hit from any kind of weapon)

- Problem Weapons: 
Same as enemies, nice weapons, specially the sword and the blaster that shoots purple thingys (which is op)
I think you should have a reason to why pick up any other weapon, other than the purple blaster, since enemies die from 1 shot and that thing has an amazing spread just spam it = Win (i was able to survive and get SSS rank by sitting in a corner spamming that gun. Since there is no reason to why pick up a slow 1 bullet per shot gun"

- Probable solution: Balancing weapons.
 *Rifle/Magnum - slow, 1 bullet per shot = Big Damage
 *Shotgun - decent spread, big damage BUT short range
 *Automatic rifle - lots of fire rate, very low spread, mid damage.
 And so on, you get the idea.

-Problem Maps:
Same, im pretty sure they will add more maps, but i think they should add more esthetic stuff to the maps, at the moment theres only 1 map and in only has these boring Tetris shaped walls and nothing more.

- Probable Solution:
When adding new maps or in the existing map, maybe add a few simple things to make it look better (depending on where the map is located at) adding stuff like wrecked cars, barrels, wrecked spaceships, stuff like that.
Maybe we can have a map located inside a spaceship?, that would be AWESOME!

Other Suggestions:
Bonus points - 
Adding  Multi-Kill bonus.
X2 Points - maybe enemies drop the X2 bonus or if you keep killing enemies without stopping for like 2-3 seconds it keeps adding up?

Abilites or Perks:
Granade: After killing X number of enemies you will be able to throw a granade that wipes the screen
Shield: Grants you immunity to only 1 hit, slow recharged time. Killing an elite or a boss reduces the cooldown
Melee: Grants you more melee range, after a multi-kill everytime you swing your sword it will throw a wave killing everything on the path.

Those are some idea that i can think of that i personally think could be fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997828885', 'num_games_owned': 398, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1463875350}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000824354', 'num_games_owned': 1300, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1439163728}
review:
There's something about these fast paced, low-res ultra violence games that bring out that primal rampage part deep within your temporal cortex. Pump that adrenalin producing game full of bassy low but fast music and hard impact effects and you get a brutal thump of a game that deserves those capital letters; UBERMOSH.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]
Simple, pure rampage fun with no frills. There are a few games developed in full by a single person ([url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/242920/]Banished[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/236090/]Dust: An Elysian Tail[/url], et al) which really shine as a result, and this is one of them.

* Low price deserves special mention, there aren't many games on Steam I can comfortably recommend at full price, this is one of those rarities
* 10 Updates within 44 days of Early Access- this title isn't going to be lost in the wind
* Good effects that work well for the low-res
* Thumping low bass soundtrack

[h1]Mistakes[/h1]
Unlike most Early Access games, there are very few issues, probably because of the games simple, hard-hitting nature. Currently the only real issue with UBERMOSH is it's lack of variety in bad guys, maps and content. There are a number of small things I'd like to see added, like Achievements, but they can't be classed as mistakes. If you're looking for reasons not to buy this, remember that it's currently being worked on full time by the developer, and anything below may have been changed since the time of review.

* The main menu is pretty unintuitive and messy. There are currently only 4 menu items and a class selector wheel, yet 90% of the title screen is taken up by the title image and the 4 selections somehow feel cluttered
* There's no reason to use anything other than the sword and the 6-Shot gun (which is currently the best gun in the game) so there's almost no variety in attacks after a certain time
* The aim-fixed camera and bobbing can cause light motion sickness for some

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

I'm usually hesitant to suggest buying Early Access, but for only Â£1.59/1.99â‚¬/$1.99 it's an oversight not to pick this one up and it's likely only going to get fuller. If you like the music featured in the promo video then it's also worth the extra Â£1.20/1.99â‚¬/$1.99 for the Soundtrack.

The one thing to hold you back is that it's likely to come up on sale for just a few pennies in the future, and will probably be all over Indie Bundles for less.

* If you're hankering for more of the awesome music, you can listen to the equally good and freely available soundtrack for [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/301480/]GEARCRACK Arena[/url], by the same developer, [url=https://soundcloud.com/gearcrack]on Soundcloud here[/url].

http://store.steampowered.com/app/357070/

author: {'steamid': '76561198053954391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1527216783}
review:
Amazing game, lots of potential. Worth the 2 dollars... the only things I hope to change or be adjusted....

- Less screen shaking for being hit or shooting the weapons. As much as I love it, it gets a lil confusing when you're hit and trying to tell the difference for when you're shooting.

- Better idea of your hitbox, I feel like at times I'm waiting too long for the bullet to come to me and the moment I think I can deflect it back I'm already hit. Maybe it's something I need to get used to but I feel as though it's hard to tell at times.

- Kinda with the first point, better sign that shows you've been hit. Maybe a red flash to indicate you've been hit or something. It's rlly difficult to keep your eye on 4 lil triangles in the top right of the screen.

- Game over screen... I know this game is meant to get high scores but the instant you die is like "THAT'S IT" and you have no idea how you died or what killed you in that instant. Not to mention winning = the same looking screen.

- I'd love more modes or longer times to last. If anything, I loved this game's combat being so simple yet so addictive. The problem with that was the time limit and only mode that just brings you short time limits to get a high score. I'd love to see a story mode or something you can explore and kill stuff around with. A mode where you're not just fighting to survive and get a high score but a mode that let's the player slaughter for hours on end.

- Multiplayer.... I'd LOVE a co-op mode, or even a 1v1 style match. Again this game has alot of potential and I don't see why it couldn't work whether it's a competition to get higher score or to kill each other.


Overall I recommend trying this game out but just remember this isn't the final stage of this game. It's good but it can be alot better. Hopefully with everyone's support and investing into the early access it can be alot better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041085059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1432402094}
review:
So I have barely played this game. I picked it up on a whim because I got a coupon out of a card combination pack. It's not a game for people like me, who enjoy slow paced and casual games, but it is an absolutely great game that I can totally recommend. It's like a poor man's version of Nuclear Throne with less weapon options and less enemy variety, but it's twice as fast and feels just as solid. 

This game has polish for how simple it is. It's a pick up and play game that you don't need to get heavily invested in. Just start it up, start slashing, and when you inevitably die or run out of time you can do it all over again. It's a tried and true formula that looks like old school but plays smoothly. If you have great reflexes and enjoy a challenging "score one-up-manship" game then give this a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136042534', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1435301488}
review:
You pick this game up for virtually nothing.
You adapt to the controls insanely quickly.
You love the soundtrack because it's amazing.
Cutting and deflecting bullets gives you that Star-Wars feeling you always wanted.
Fast paced fun you can play for either a few minutes or as long as you like.
This game will probably hone your reaction-skills over the top, because you're moving your mouse around like a maniac to deflect bullets from the left while trying to shoot at enemies on your right while pedaling backwards in order to avoid other spawns.

Overall: This game = 10/10. Had mad fun in the few minutes I played and will definitely play it again, most likely every day.
I would love to see this game in a few months, to see what the devs make out of it. This thing does have a LOT of potential, USE IT.

P.S: Of course everyone would love a co-op mode or even a pvp arena where guns are all over the floor and everyone is killing everything.

I say: Support this game because it has insane amounts of potential and is mad fun, whether you play for hours on end or  mere minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131348759', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1526707962}

author: {'steamid': '76561198086134406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1540580649}
review:
At it's core, Ubermosh is one of the best retro shooters out there. It keeps gameplay a simple matter of beating your high score in a 16 bit arena full of respawning goons, like a super-basic isometric-ish Unreal Tournament. There are 4 different weapons to choose from, and a melee weapon that can reflect bullets back at enemies, which (aside from melee which you start with) you get by killing off aforementioned goons, and the game objective is as simple as this: Kill as many opponents in the 90 second time limit as possible while not getting killed yourself.

It's a staggeringly simple concept that for the most part is excellently implemented. Right now, there is only very barebones content, but the game price is reflecting this, and where many games have tons of content but are seriously lacking in enjoyment, Ubermosh is great fun to play and easy to lose hours playing due to it's dip in/dip out gameplay.

That said, the only dark cloud on this game is that it's early access and developer Walter (it's a one man game team) isn't quite happy with the brass tacks of the gameplay mechanic yet. As such, minor but significant changes are happening within the game all the time (I've had the game about a month max and it's been radically overhauled 10 times already, each time significantly changing the play style required) and right now, each update is resetting your score, which for a game that is purely score-attack and score-attack only can be disheartening and frustrating.

If you want to support a hard-working solo developer intent on making a well-balanced arcade throwback, and play a game that isn't finished yet but already has piles of one-more-go addictive gameplay, then buy it now.

If you feel having said game continuously morph overnight into different adaptations of said gameplay, or indeed losing your progress each time it morphs is going to upset you in anyway, I would advise you to wait til Ubermosh comes out of Early Access, because Walter is still very much actively working on it, and as such sometimes it has features added for as little as 4 hours until he decides actually they weren't a good idea. Which if he's reading is absolutely fine, that's development xD. But be aware that the game is being built in front of us.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012885996', 'num_games_owned': 776, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1705491529}
review:
Wow, let me just start off by saying this is easily the most fun I've ever had for $1.99. Hell, I've purchased 'Triple A' (By whose standards?) games for 30 times that and stopped playing after an hour. Buy this game now while it's cheap and still amazing.

[h1]Liked[/h1]
------
Pretty much the whole thing. Quick, easy to pick up, and hard as [b]HELL[/b]. Soundtrack is tight too.
------
[h1]Disliked[/h1]
------
The game as it is now, is great. There's not a whole lot I would change. My main dislike at this point is the lack of content. But of course as the game's development progresses, more content should be added.
------
[h1]Developer Suggestions[/h1]
------
Besides more content(i.e. maps, skins, weapons, achievements), I have a few suggestions I think would improve this game a little more:
[list]
[*]Add a "pickup" key, for example space bar, that has to be held down to pick up a weapon. Not really major, but I personally found it annoying dodging guns I didn't want as well as enemies.
[*]Implement some sort of "forced movement"(e.g. stand still lose health) mechanic, for sure. This I think is pretty crucial. Not just for added difficulty but for enjoyment. The game is more fun the more hectic and twitchy it is. Forcing movement will prevent picking up the red scatter gun and just camping a spot.
[/list]
------
[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
If you like twitchy, quick, arcade like games, pull out your plastic right now. For $1.99, this alpha is a must-have. The developer is actively updating to make it even better. Don't wait for it to be out of alpha, and get a huge price increase(hopefully, this game is [i]So Good[/i]). Support the development right now, and get [b]UBERMOSH(ing)[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198052898849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1429462754}
review:
O jogo Ã© muito bom! Esta com uma jogabilidade otima! Pena que eu nao tenho dedos para acompanhar a velocidade do game! A se eu fosse usar apenas uma palavra para descrever o jogo seria FRENÃ‰TICO. 
As atualizaÃ§Ãµes recentes tem tornado o jogo mais dinamico e dificil, Perco horas jogando!


Aqui vÃ£o duas dicas que poderiam ser incorporadas ao jogo para jogadores mais noobs como eu:

author: {'steamid': '76561197983548320', 'num_games_owned': 3595, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1563719042}
review:
Below you'll find a written and video impression on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GAJ8VEdzvwU

Ubermosh is a pretty simple game. Jump into it, use your giant blade to kill your foes and to reflect their bullets back at them. Pick up weapons from fallen enemies and use it to your advantage. Get as much kills as possible with'n the game's time limit with out dying, rinse, improve your score, and repeat.

Aesthetically I don't have much complaints. I like the pixel art and the sound track is amazing, it might be my favorite part of the game and hope to see the OST released for sale in the future.

Ubermosh isn't very expensive, about $2.00 USD, and the content reflect the price. There's not a whole lot here, no multiplayer, no extra modes or features, it's just going to be score attack over and over again. Luckily for us, what is here currently is great! The combat is a lot of fun and well designed. It's challenging with a high skill ceiling, and as mentioned before, the music is amazing. Ubermosh is currently in early access, so that could explain the lack of content, but hopefully we'll see much more added to the game as I feel like it has a lot of potential.

Overall Ubermosh has a lot of promise. The combat is exciting, the music is fantastic, and the challenge is enjoyable, I just want to see a lot more of all these things in the near future.

Pros:
- Great visuals and audio, especially the music
- Very reasonable price ($2.00 USD)
- Fun combat

Cons:
- Needs a lot more content

author: {'steamid': '76561198025037510', 'num_games_owned': 6279, 'num_reviews': 339, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1454432357}
review:
[b]EARLY ACCESS REVIEW originally posted at [url=www.apochs.net]Apoch's Metal Review[/url].[/b]

Walter Machado, developer of last year's PC Action title [b]Gearcrack Arena[/b], returns with a brand new venture simply titled [b]Ubermosh[/b]. While the follow-up release isn't quite done, Walter has gone ahead and made it available through Steam as an "Early Access" purchase at a nice budgetary cost of two dollars US (cheaper if you picked it up on sale around the time of launch). But, what exactly is it, and, even at this point in development, is it anything worth keeping an eye on?

[b]Ubermosh[/b] is being described as "a shot of adrenaline", offering an experience similar to that of "a pinball table or a coin arcade machine" according to the game's "about" section. In its current state, you play as an unnamed protagonist in a Cyber Punk world with growing hordes of opponents you need to defeat in order to survive the imposed time limit. It's kind of like the atmosphere of a [b]Shadowrun[/b] title laced with the core principles of [b]Robotron 2084[/b]. The only difference is that, as time goes on, it seems to escalate into a Bullet Hell style offering sans the SHMUP style of gameplay.

While it would work nicely as a twin stick shooter, this is more a keyboard and mouse operation on par with [b]Alien Breed[/b] or [b]Shadowgrounds[/b], but in a tightly confined space. The keys allow you to race around the field, while the mouse moves the targeting reticle and acts as your mode of attack. The main goal is to deflect bullets from your foes in order to survive, not to mention acquire their ranged weaponry. Of course, if you're like me, you'll probably get more enjoyment out of slicing your opponents in half with your sword than shooting long distance with the various guns that become available.

The problem right now with this idea is that, when you fire so much as a single shot, you automatically pick up any new weapon you run over, changing the firing method. So, say you have a spread shot of some sort, and you prefer it or just have gotten accustomed to it this time around. If you run over another weapon, you might acquire a thin laser shot or bulky bullets instead, which changes the whole dynamic of your ranged attacks. A lot of this seems to depend on the enemy you kill as well, so avoiding their aptly color coded guns for the sake of sticking with the one you prefer can be a little more tedious when it comes to that shot of adrenaline you're looking for.

Recently there was an update that added in a level boss. This enemy, when defeated, would drop a special gun that will never replace any others scattered about the battle field. It's a nice little perk that seems to have longer range and take out more foes grouped together compared to the single bullet deaths of these one-hit-kill enemies. Sadly, there's no major indicator of who the level boss is unless you know all the standard minions, which isn't too hard after a while since there seems to only be a handful of various character designs at the moment. The first time I even knew I had killed the boss was because I had a gun that acted differently compared to the others, not to mention could not be replaced by walking over any others. It would be nice to have some sort of indicator so that gamers know where that objective is within the swarm of enemies rushing you. It doesn't need to point off screen either, maybe just a little downwar arrow above its head when it comes into frame.

The amount of terrain also seems fairly limited right now, only keeping with rather flat color palettes within the randomly generated outdoors world. Hopefully in future builds we'll see levels inside or designs that better reflect the Cyber Punk universe this world is meant to take place in, but, for now, those flat, earthy tones clash with the brighter colors of enemies to help you discern foes to an extent. Regardless of how observant you are, you're still going to miss one or two wandered into frame or appeared out of nowhere.

Finally there's the mixture of Industrial and Metal instrumentals that make up the soundtrack. The sound effects are decent for the eight-bit style Arcade graphics on display, and the faster speed and pacing of the horde growth are both well done to play up the adrenaline side of things. It's all just complimented by static, tribal drum rhythms, or a harsher, grittier battle soundtrack that many developers nowadays would have no problem slapping Alternative Rock songs onto to cater to a wider audience. It seems as though Walter is aware of just who will be playing this title and is focusing on making those individuals happy, something I thank him greatly for.

So, as it stands, this is a quick game of randomly generated terrain you need to run around in and destroy enemies by deflecting bullets or cutting them in half with your sword, only to pick up their guns and start blasting around, all within a very limited amount of time. For as basic a core concept as that is, [b]Ubermosh[/b] is an incredibly fun little top down Action game that challenges you to beat your previous score with each new round. The title screen displays your top kill amount up to this point (though the last update reset that for me, so future ones may do the same), allowing for instant bragging rights among friends, or a challenge if one happens to surpass it while playing under your name. There's also an option for extras, but there's none available at this time, so there's that to either look forward to, or dread. Hopefully it's just for small things like community downloadable content alterations or simple gimmicks like options to make everyone have clown heads or silly things like that.

[b]Ubermosh[/b] isn't the most expansive at the moment either, and there's clearly more to come from the roughly year long development the early access outline points out. Hopefully those future additions or alterations won't nerf the challenge or destroy the established classic arcade style game play that makes this idea as a whole work. There are many comparisons to the game [b]Nuclear Throne[/b] as well, which I can't really comment on as I haven't played it yet. They do look similar, but that's all based on the few trailers I've seen. But, in the end, if you happen to have a couple dollars on your Steam account and want something you can kill five or ten minutes with, [b]Ubermosh[/b] is definitely well worth it at this point in time. You probably won't run marathon gaming sessions, but as a casual pick-up-and-play offering, it's an intense little ride you won't soon regret.

[i]Overall Score: 9/10[/i]

review:
There is not much content as of right now, but I still like it. It feels [i]very[/i] Nuclear Throne-ish. Thats a good thing. The developer has commented on how there are slight conceptual differences, but all-in-all its a pretty sick run-and-gun affair. It feels good playing it. Controls are very tight, and graphical style is cool. Music is very good too.

Overall, I really hope alot more is added, but at this price (a measly two bucks) I can solidly recommend it now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971532357', 'num_games_owned': 2752, 'num_reviews': 413, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1580566218}
review:
It is time to update the review, as it's been more than two years since this early access text:

You'll tell me that I have a few minutes in the game. True. But well, from what I've played, I was really charmed by it. Old-school arcade shooter with a punching soundtrack, simple as hell (well to understand) and that idea that the blade can send back bullets... I'm already in mode trying to send them all.

Walter Machado listened to us, people used to arrows for moving or AZERTY users used to ZQSD (which is our equivalent of WASD for QWERTY). He updated the game so that we can finally play with more ease (try to do WASD on AZERTY and you'll be killed after a few seconds). And well, since that, I've confirmed my first impression that UBERMOSH is a little gem. For the price, you'll not be robbed.

While the graphisms are clearly influenced by retro-gaming and what we used to have before, I can still see that huge blade, that nice characters and well.... Yep, completely charmed by it.

Keep doing the good work!

--------

As you can see, I was really enthusiast for the game and if you look at my library, I've bought the soundtrack and the sequels, despite the fact that it could have been DLC, but hey, Walter's choice and I'm supporting it as UBERMOSH is really worthy of being bought.

Yeah, I've spent less that 8 hours in the game, in the two years I've begun playing it. But UBERMOSH isn't done to be played hours straigh, it's done to play 10 to 20 minutes, as a break from other games.

Walter Machado really listened to the community, as I've said, and I must say that I'm quite proud to have achieved 100% of achievements, as the game isn't as easy as it seems.

There is no real plot apart that you're in an arena, without guns but with your sword that can reflect bullets. Enemies are coming and the goal is to survive 90 seconds of them, with limited lives and by picking up guns (once you have the most powerful, it stays on). The arena is randomly build: you have rocks that can serve as a cover or obstacles. It's also limited by flashy inscriptions: cross them and you're finishing the round.

There are different modes:
* No Class Mods: basic mode, with four respawns (lifes), you begin with only your blade.
* Kensai: you're only using your sword, no gun can be picked but you have six respawns
* Gunner: you don't have any sword, but you spawn with a basic gun which is firing automatically (keep your finger on the left click of your mouse - which is the full auto feature as in other modes, you need to always click to fire) and you have three respawns
* Warlock: you have already the better gun (AND your sword), but it's not firing automatically (you have to keep clicking to make it work) and you have two respawns only.

Like I've said in my earlier review, the game is clearly made with retro-gaming in the head: graphics are quite reminiscing of an early era of video games. But I love the colors changing at each new rounds.

The soundtrack is also very great: guitars for a sci-fi feel. Yeah, that's how I will describe it.

I have only one problem: the fact that I'm sometimes running in ennemies when going down or up that are spawning or firing from outside the screen. It's just annoying but well, it's part of the life in UBERMOSH.

Seriously, go ahead. And given the fact that I'm also playing BLACK and Vol. 3 mean only something: the whole series is a gem and really addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131699677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1709899074}
review:
UBERMOSH is a GREAT game.

Not an epic, not a great on the sense that Civilization or Mario are... That's not a game that you will need to have 399 hours to complete. Not even one. Is a game that last 90 secons (IF you are good at it).

I played a lot, died a lot. Had TONS of fun. And then there i see "19 minuts of gameplay". How the hell, 19 minutes, I asked myself.

Yeah, most of the time i got only 20-30 seconds boefore I got myself killed. Then I hit "play" and returned, and killed, and died. Repeat.

The soundtrack is just outstanding. Fast beats, rapid fire of guitars and electronic drums, definitively creates the atmosphere of "mash your mouse buttons for your life!". And then there are monster spawning and firing at you, and you have a sort-of-jedi-sword that can deflect bullets! And it will save your life so so many times in this game.

It's an Anphetaminic game.

review: It's a great arcady top down shooter with cool artwork. The game is still under development so there is not that much content yet. You fight in an arena against endlessly spawning enemies and have to get as many kills as possible in 90 seconds. You can deflect bullets with your sword which is a nice addition to the shooter gameplay. The enemies drop different kinds of weapons you can pick up. I really like the fast paced industrial metal soundtrack which fits the gameplay perfectly. The game plus the music really give you this nice feeling of flow. A bit like Super Hexagon or Hotline Miami. It's dirt cheap right now so definitely get it and support the devs to add more content and make it even better!

author: {'steamid': '76561198104955068', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1438142595}
review:
Sound:Why is the sound so loud, AND I can't adjust it? I don't dislike the loud music, the bass is so bumpin' that I fell in love immediately. I just like the option of lowering it so I can hear my Skype call better, it will most likely be fixed in full release. Also, Morgan Freeman is the narrator.
Looks: I had an instant eyegasm, it's neon and I love it. It looks like an insane space Hotline Miami; IN SPACE!
Story: Lol it's a timed arena see how long you can last type of game.
Mosh on, uber-ly.
7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198144974149', 'num_games_owned': 3847, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1524599378}
review:
From the developer of GEARCRACK Arena (the game infamous for the reviews that read "Buy it for pennies, sell the cards, make a profit, listen to the music.").

I enjoy GEARCRACK for what it is, and now with UBERMOSH, hopefully people will realize what Walter Machado strives for when developing games (thus nullifying the undue dogpiling and (")nit-picky-ness(")): Simple Arcade Diversions. 
For the money, it is truly appalling just how vehement other reviews have condemned GEARCRACK, especially when some other games in the â€œBargain Binâ€ that cost more than thrice it arenâ€™t as commensurate at entertaining. UBERMOSH is already leaps and bounds better than GEARCRACK (I say with an attempt at a sympathetic-to-the-consensus viewpoint), though Iâ€™m hoping that one of the new game modes planned for UBERMOSH will be reminiscent of GEARCRACK in having little to nothing explained (which was a throwback to games from the â€˜90â€™s (a la System Shock 2, perhaps)). 

The only legitimate criticism of GEARCRACK was that nothing was explained; go to the forums to discover that a lot of variables are determined by RNG. So people concluded that the (")hardcore(") aspects of the game were simply (")unfair("). 
I thought that was half the fun of GEARCRACK â€“ I feel those who complained forgot just how much they paid for the game (not to suggest that price absolves a game of criticism, as Walter knows).
http://steamcommunity.com/app/301480/discussions/0/616189742994052573/

UBERMOSH plays much like GEARCRACK but in a much more refined and simplistic manner. There are (at this time) really no discernible nuances. You run around an arena with hordes of enemies pursuing you. You can deflect enemy fire; you can directly melee the enemies; you can pick up their weapons. 
GEARCRACK had enemies with shields that required you use certain implicit tactics to destroy them; limited ammunition; an incredibly short time-limit that assaulted you along with unbelievable barrages from the enemies [i]as soon as[/i] you took an action.

I've little doubt that UBERMOSH will have more complex features added later - it will not be nothing but a "serviceable diversion," as I called GEARCRACK - but, to be sure, (it seems) that is Walter's goal. 
People can complain about GEARCRACK and it's possible that the basis for those qualms won't necessarily be baseless. 
The only complaint (thus far) that can be recorded of UBERMOSH (besides just how early of a version the game is in (clicking on "Extras" (where I would assume some sort of Options would be) does nothing but remind you "Non-final version")) is that "there's nothing to it." 
This is a simple arcade game. Your goal is to beat your previous scores. The action is incredibly hectic and very fun. As it is, it isnâ€™t necessary to have a levelling system, a customizable arsenal, a level select feature, etc.; the basic gameplay is such that progression driven by the self is enough to ensure fun (not to suggest "Good game Walter, we're content, you can be done with updates," lol). [strike]Any score you've previously achieved is wiped upon exiting the game;[/strike] there's always room for you to get better at the game.


...I actually regret buying this game while it is discounted. I just saw it and immediately bought it because I have hope that Walter Machado will continue to be a great indie developer and that heâ€™ll achieve success. 
Walter is worthy of your support; the flak that GEARCRACK received is not applicable to UBERMOSH (and I contest that, though the criticism of the former wasnâ€™t undue, GEARCRACK did not deserve the [i]amount[/i] of criticism it received â€“ those â€œMixedâ€ user reviews). 

I recommend this (and Walterâ€™s previous) game.

DISCLOSURE: I posted a screenshot of UBERMOSH on my profile. I like to show discounted games however I can on there - my Game Collector showcase was full - took a screenshot of my score just to have UBERMOSH shown on my page.
That screenshot has had 1 upvote; my review has No ratings yet.
Walter Machado sent me a friend request. I have to assume it was... because of my screenshot? Or perhaps he has read my review and, in the interest of integrity, just did not vote either way on it.
Say all that to say: I wrote this review (as with all my reviews) according to my own opinion - it was not endorsed in any way by Walter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071408759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1449078457}
review:
Great game, it's an arcade style game where you're put in an arena for 90 seconds, you start off with your sword that can split bullets and you collect weapons from your enemies dead bodies, it's extremely addictive, it has great music, and everything in this game is done by one man, Walter Machado.

Edit: after finding any bugs, I spoke to Walter and he immediatley went and fixed it, he's got a great response and is always checking the forums what people have to say!

review: This is a Great game. The music is amazing, retro art is very efficient for the style of the game. author: {'steamid': '76561198053422627', 'num_games_owned': 2391, 'num_reviews': 1237, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1506009485}
review:
First Play on early access Launch Day Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fsjgQ_ot8UU

This game is pure win.

Old school game mechanics, but ubermosh is uber-fun!  

The game is easy to understand with WASD movement, left click to shoot, right click to swing your sword.
The game is hard to master as enemies are relentless and come at you from every angle.  

Surviving the first 90 seconds is a challenge in itself!

Super addicting game play makes you want to play over and over, even if you are getting your butt owned like myself when I first started.

MUST BUY for any old school arcade/action game fans!  $1.99 is a steal for this much fun, enuf' said.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009094932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1451347282}
review:
Game is intense.  If you are into the Geometry Wars series, Luftrausers, or Nuclear Throne, you are prolly going to like this game.  Also.  Yes.  As far as I can tell that is none other than Morgan Freeman in the trailer.  ;)

//+PROS:

- Addictive...
- Smooth...
- Fun...
- One of the best Swords in the history of videogames.  It is so smooth and reacts AMZAINGLY when you cut the enemies bullets into pieces and send them flying back at them to rupture their delicate skin-sacks open!
- Each match is only 90 seconds (if you can survive it), so it is great for a quick jaunt of BOOM-BOOM-SLASH.
- Can't really beat the price now can you?  I got it for $2 something (CAD).

//-CONS:

- Would like a music mute button.  That's it.  Not that the music is bad, it fits the game rather well -- just having heard it for the hundredth time made me want the ability to mute it if I so choose.
- Would like more content, but I am sure that it's to come!
- Not really alot to complain about.

I can definitely see myself playing UBERMOSH quite often when I have a little time to kill.

SHOOT-SLASH-SHOOT-SLASH-SLASH-SLASH!

Would HIGHLY recommend -- especially at the price!

TLDR; Best Morgan Freeman impersonation currently available on STEAM, 10/10 Skrimshaw Reductions, err Shawskkankk Resplendants... whatever.  Get busy Livin' or get busy dyin'.
